document.title: Gibbs measures and the Ising model

para.p:
Let
Λ
be a finite subset of
Z 2
and let
=
Λ ′
∖
Z 2
Λ
. Let
∈
σ ′
{
- 1
,
+ 1
}
Λ ′
, a fixed configuration of spins outside
Λ
. Let
= Ω
{
- 1
,
+ 1
}
Λ
;
Ω
is the space of all configurations of spins on
Λ
. We define a Hamiltonian
H Λ
( ⋅ |
σ ′
)
: Ω → R
(depending on the fixed external configuration
σ ′
) by

Math.text: H _ Lambda * conditional@(sigma, sigma ^ prime) = - (sum _ ((absolute-value@(x - y) = 1) ^ (list@(x, y) element-of Lambda)))@(sigma * x * sigma * y) - (sum _ ((absolute-value@(x - y) = 1) ^ (formulae@(x element-of Lambda, y element-of Lambda ^ prime))))@(sigma * x * sigma ^ prime * y)

para.p:
H Λ
( ⋅ |
σ ′
)
gives the energy of a configuration
∈ σ Ω
, conditioned on the external configuration
σ ′
.

For a parameter
> β 0
(called the inverse temperature), we define the partition function by

Math.text: Z * vector@(beta, Lambda, sigma ^ prime) = (sum _ (sigma element-of Omega))@(exponential@(- beta * H _ Lambda * conditional@(sigma, sigma ^ prime)))

para.p:
Then we define the Gibbs distribution for the configuration space
Ω
, depending on the external configuration
σ ′
, by

Math.text: P _ (list@(beta, Lambda)) * conditional@(sigma, sigma ^ prime) = (1 / (Z * vector@(beta, Lambda, sigma ^ prime))) * exponential@(- beta * H * conditional@(sigma, sigma ^ prime))

para.p:
The purpose of the partition function is to normalize the above expression to be a probability measure on the configuration space
Ω
.

For example, let
Λ
be a square of side length
3
centred at the origin, and take
σ ′
to be an external configuration of all negative spins. Define
∈ σ Ω
by

Math.text: Array[[sigma * open-interval@(- 1, 1) = + 1, sigma * open-interval@(0, 1) = + 1, sigma * open-interval@(1, 1) = - 1], [sigma * open-interval@(- 1, 0) = - 1, sigma * open-interval@(0, 0) = + 1, sigma * open-interval@(1, 0) = - 1], [sigma * open-interval@(- 1, - 1) = - 1, sigma * open-interval@(0, - 1) = - 1, sigma * open-interval@(1, - 1) = + 1]]

para.p:
We show this configuration in Figure . We calculate that the energy of this configuration is
=
⁢
H Λ
(
| σ
σ ′
)
0
. We can calculate the energy of this configuration in a different way, using line segments separating lattice points with different spins, as follows. For an
× n n
square, there are
⁢ 2 n
(
+ n 1
)
nearest neighbor interactions. Put a line segment between every two lattice points with different spins; let
⁢ B
(
| σ
σ ′
)
be the set of these line segments. We show this in Figure .

para.p:
Generally, if
Λ
is an
× n n
square then we have

Indeed, in our above example,
= n 3
and
| B
( σ |
σ ′
)
| = 12
, so the above expression is
=
+
- 24
⋅ 2 12
0
, and we have already calculated that
=
⁢
H Λ
(
| σ
σ ′
)
0
. What matters is that if we know the external configuration, then to describe the configuration inside a region
Λ
it suffices to know the edges that separate opposite spins. And since the energy of any configuration has the term
-
⁢ 2 n
(
+ n 1
)
and this appears in the numerator and denominator of the expression for the Gibbs distribution, we can omit it to calculate the Gibbs distribution. By a contour we mean a closed path of edges that does not intersect itself. We can express the Gibbs distribution in terms of contours as

Math.text: P _ (list@(beta, Lambda)) * conditional@(sigma, sigma ^ prime) = (product _ (gamma element-of Gamma * open-interval@(sigma, sigma ^ prime)))@(exponential@(- 2 * absolute-value@(gamma))) / (sum _ Gamma)@((product _ (gamma element-of Gamma))@(exponential@(- 2 * beta * absolute-value@(gamma))))

para.p:
⁢ Γ
( σ ,
σ ′
)
is the set of contours corresponding to the configuration
σ
with the external configuration
σ ′
, and the summation is over all sets
Γ
of nonintersecting contours.

We are not in fact interested in the Gibbs distribution on the configurations on a finite subset
Λ
of
Z 2
, but instead limits of Gibbs distributions with
→
Λ n
Z 2
. A Gibbs distribution
P
β , Λ
( ⋅ |
σ ′
)
on
Ω
is in fact a probability measure on
{
+ 1
,
- 1
}
Z 2
: for
∈ σ
{
+ 1
,
- 1
}
Z 2
, a configuration on the plane, we define

Math.text: (widetilde@(P)) _ (list@(beta, Lambda)) * conditional@(sigma, sigma ^ prime) = cases@(0, conditional@(sigma, Lambda ^ prime) not-equals sigma ^ prime, P _ (list@(beta, Lambda)) * conditional@(conditional@(sigma, Lambda), sigma ^ prime), conditional@(sigma, Lambda ^ prime) = sigma ^ prime)

para.p:
Fix some
β
. Let
Λ n
be a sequence of
× n n
squares centred at the origin, let
σ
n , +
′
be a sequence of external configurations where all lattice points outside
Λ n
have positive spins, and let
σ
n , -
′
be a sequence of external configurations where all lattice points outside
Λ n
have negative spins. Let
P
n , +
be the sequence of Gibbs distributions corresponding to the positive external spins, and let
P
n , -
be the sequence of Gibbs distributions corresponding to the negative external spins. These extend to probability measures
~ P
n , +
and
~ P
n , -
on
{
+ 1
,
- 1
}
Z 2
. Since
{
+ 1
,
- 1
}
is a compact metrizable space, the product
{
+ 1
,
- 1
}
Z 2
is a compact metrizable space and thus the space of probability measures on it is compact. Hence the sequence
~ P
n , +
has at least one limit point, say
P +
, and the sequence
~ P
n , -
has at least one limit point, say
P -
. We shall show that
≠
P +
P -
, namely that there is not a unique limit Gibbs measure on the set of all configurations on
Z 2
.

Let
=
V +
{
∈ σ
{
+ 1
,
- 1
}
Z 2
:
=
⁢ σ
( 0 )
+ 1
}
and
=
V -
{
∈ σ
{
+ 1
,
- 1
}
Z 2
:
=
⁢ σ
( 0 )
- 1
}
. Suppose that for all
n
we had
<
⁢
~ P
n , +
(
V -
)
1 3
. Taking limits we have that
≤
⁢
P +
(
V -
)
1 3
and so
≥
⁢
P +
(
V +
)
2 3
(since the events
V +
and
V -
are disjoint and their union is the set of all configurations on
Z 2
). But
=
⁢
~ P
n , +
(
V -
)
⁢
~ P
n , -
(
V +
)
, so taking limits we also get
≤
⁢
P -
(
V +
)
1 3
. Therefore the measures
P +
and
P -
give different measures to the set
V +
, so they are distinct. Thus to show that the measures
P +
and
P -
are distinct it suffices to show that for all
n
we have
<
⁢
~ P
n , +
(
V -
)
1 3
.

The above sum is over all contours such that the origin lies in their interior. We can write the set of all contours around the origin as a union of the set of all contours of length
k
around the origin,
≥ k 4
. There are at most
⁢
(
k 4
)
2
4 k
contours of length
k
around the origin. Therefore

Math.text: (widetilde@(P)) _ (list@(n, +)) * V _ - less= ((sum _ (k = 4)) ^ infinity)@(((k ^ 2 / 16) cdot 4 ^ k) * exponential@(- 2 * beta * k))

para.p:
As
→ β ∞
, this is
⁢ O
(
exp
(
-
⁢ 8 β
)
)
. In particular there is some
β 0
such that if
≥ β
β 0
then for all
n
we have
<
⁢

n , +

V -
)
1 3
. This shows that the limit Gibbs measures gives different measures to the set
V +
, hence they are distinct.
Minlos [], Sinai [], Cipra [], Simon [], Le Ny [], Kadanoff [].
